title: UK warns Turkey it will 'oppose' any invasion of northern Syria in the wake of Trump troop pullout
text:
Mr Trump today continued to defend Washington's relationship with Recep Erdogan's regime after a bipartisan backlash over his decision on Monday

Britain will not support any invasion of northern Syria by Turkish troops, a minister warned today, after Donald Trump ordered US forces to leave the area and leave their Kurdish allies defenceless.

Foreign Office Minister Andrew Murrison said Britain would 'oppose' any military incursion by its Nato ally in the wake of the widely-criticised American pull-out.

Mr Trump today continued to defend Washington's relationship with Recep Erdogan's regime after a bipartisan backlash over his decision on Monday.

Critics fear the move will open the way for a Turkish strike on Kurdish-led forces long allied with Washington who have led the fight against the Islamic State militant group in Syria.

Turkey says those forces are terrorists because of their ties to Kurdish militants who have waged a long insurgency in Turkey.

Dr Murrison told the Commons today: 'We would oppose any incursion by our good friend and Nato ally Turkey into Syria.'

Turkey, led by Recep Erdogan (pictured today) says Kurdish forces are terrorists because of their ties to Kurdish militants who have waged a long insurgency in Turkey

Foreign Office Minister Andrew Murrison said Britain would 'oppose' any military incursion by its Nato ally in the wake of the widely-criticised American pull-out

It came as the US decision faced condemnation from across the political spectrum, both int he UK and the US.

Tory chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee Tom Tugendhat said: 'Here we've found ourselves surprised by the actions of our most important ally and our allies on the ground surprised at the possibility they may find their homes under very serious threat from one of our other more important military allies in Turkey.

'Will the minister please assure me that our other allies in the region are being assured that the UK will not make a pattern of being fair-weather friends but will actually commit to our allies seriously and properly?'

And former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said: 'Can we make it very clear publicly, not just to the Americans, that we disapprove of this, but more importantly to the Turks that, if they do carry out their threat, that we will consider this to be an aggressive act against ourselves as much as we would against the Kurds?'

While the Government has been quick to criticise Turkey, Dr Murrison refused to condemn Donald Trump's decision, saying said: 'We are not complicit with any action the US may or may not take. This is a matter for the US. We have made our position absolutely clear.'

The Prime Minister's official spokesman also sidestepped the US decision, saying the Turkish actions were 'deeply concerning'.

Syrian Kurds carry flags and banners as they demonstrate against Turkish threats to launch a military operation on their region, in the town of Al-Qahtaniyah, in north east Syria

Turkish forces artillery pieces are seen on their new positions near the border with Syria in Sanliurfa province last weekend

'The UK has been consistently clear with Turkey that unilateral military action must be avoided as it would destabilise the region and threaten efforts to secure the lasting defeat of Daesh,' he added.

Earlier Mr Trump hailed Turkey as a 'big trading partner' in a tweet.

'They have also been good to deal with ... Also remember, and importantly, that Turkey is an important member in good standing of NATO,' he added.

He also insisted Washington was not abandoning the Kurdish-led forces, writing: 'We may be in the process of leaving Syria, but in no way have we Abandoned the Kurds, who are special people and wonderful fighters.'

The Kurdish-led forces have said they may launch talks with Damascus or Moscow to fill a security vacuum in the event of a full US withdrawal from the area.

The Turkish Defence Ministry said late on Monday that it had completed preparations for a possible military operation in northeastern Syria.
